description.short: Measures vulnerability to systematic avoidance of security decision-making during high-stress situations, creating dangerous delays that attackers exploit
description.context: Flight response avoidance manifests when security personnel systematically avoid making critical security decisions or confronting security issues during high-stress situations, instead deferring, delegating, or delaying action. This psychological pattern creates dangerous security gaps because attackers exploit the decision delays and avoidance behaviors to maintain persistence and expand their access during the crucial early phases when containment would be most effective.
description.impact: Organizations with flight response patterns experience unexplained delays in incident response, reluctance to escalate security issues, and security decisions that become stuck in committee during critical moments. Attackers time their activities during periods when key personnel exhibit avoidance behaviors, such as end-of-quarter business pressure or major system updates. Historical incidents include Target (2013) and Equifax (2017) where delayed responses to initial breach indicators allowed extended attacker dwell time.
description.psychological_basis: Polyvagal Theory (Porges, 2011) shows flight response represents activation of the sympathetic nervous system's mobilization branch when social engagement fails. Seligman's Learned Helplessness Research (1972) demonstrates that repeated exposure to uncontrollable stressors leads to generalized avoidance behaviors. Cognitive Load Theory (Sweller, 1988) shows excessive cognitive demands lead to systematic avoidance of complex tasks as a protective mechanism against cognitive overload.

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 ï¿½ Quick_Assessment + w2 ï¿½ Conversation_Depth + w3 ï¿½ Red_Flags) ï¿½ Interdependency_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Security decisions consistently made within 4 hours during incidents, clear escalation paths with documented authority at each level, security personnel regularly attend incident meetings (>90% attendance), delegation follows documented procedures with clear handoffs, complex issues have defined resolution processes with timeframes, no observable pattern of decision delays during high-stress periods, and authority conflicts resolved through documented processes within 24 hours.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Security decisions delayed 4-24 hours during incidents, escalation paths exist but authority boundaries unclear in some scenarios, security personnel attendance at incident meetings inconsistent (70-90%), some delegation occurs without clear procedures, complex issues sometimes delayed beyond necessary analysis time, occasional patterns of slower decision-making under stress, and authority conflicts sometimes require external intervention to resolve.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: Security decisions delayed >24 hours during incidents or indefinitely postponed, unclear escalation paths or authority boundaries for security decisions, frequent absence from security meetings or incident response (<70% attendance), regular informal delegation without procedures or accountability, complex issues routinely deferred or avoided rather than resolved, consistent patterns of decision avoidance during high-stress situations, and authority conflicts remain unresolved or create ongoing security gaps.

mathematical_model.primary: D_7.4(t) = AI(t) ï¿½ P_flight(t) ï¿½ (1 + ï¿½ ï¿½ criticality(t))

flight_probability.description: Flight response probability based on stress, trait anxiety, and environmental constraints

task_abandonment.description: Task abandonment rate measuring security tasks started but not completed
task_abandonment.interpretation: Higher values indicate systematic avoidance of completing security tasks

session_termination.description: Session termination acceleration compared to baseline
session_termination.interpretation: Positive values indicate premature session termination suggesting avoidance

avoidance_index.description: Composite avoidance index combining task abandonment, session termination, and response delays

P_flight.calculation: Flight response probability from stress and anxiety indicators
P_flight.query: SELECT [e^(alpha*stress + beta*anxiety)] / [1 + e^(alpha*stress + beta*anxiety)] * (1-constraint) FROM stress_metrics WHERE time_window='1h'

TAR.query: SELECT (COUNT(abandonment_flag=true) / COUNT(*)) FROM task_logs WHERE assigned_to IN security_team AND timestamp > NOW() - INTERVAL '7 days'

delay_response.calculation: Average response delay for security communications
delay_response.query: SELECT AVG(response_latency) FROM communication_logs WHERE participant_id IN security_team AND message_type='security_critical' AND time_window='24h'

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Decision Timeline Tracking
items.question: How long does it typically take your organization to make critical security decisions during an incident (from identification to action)?

options.label: Security decisions consistently made within 4 hours during incidents with clear decision points
Security decisions delayed 4-24 hours during incidents with some procedural delays
Security decisions delayed >24 hours during incidents or indefinitely postponed

items.evidence_required: Recent incident timelines showing time from identification to action decision

items.title: Escalation Authority Clarity
items.question: When security personnel encounter issues requiring difficult decisions, what is your standard escalation procedure?

options.label: Clear escalation paths with documented authority at each level for all decision types
Escalation paths exist but authority boundaries unclear in some scenarios
Unclear escalation paths or authority boundaries for security decisions

items.evidence_required: Escalation procedure documentation, recent escalation examples with authority clarity

items.title: Meeting and Communication Patterns
items.question: How consistent is key security personnel attendance at security incident meetings?

options.label: Security personnel regularly attend incident meetings (>90% attendance) with documented participation
Security personnel attendance at incident meetings inconsistent (70-90%)
Frequent absence from security meetings or incident response (<70% attendance)

items.evidence_required: Meeting attendance records for security incidents over past 90 days

items.title: Delegation During Crisis
items.question: What happens when your primary security decision-makers are unavailable during incidents?

options.label: Delegation follows documented procedures with clear handoffs and authority transfer
Some delegation occurs without clear procedures or complete documentation
Regular informal delegation without procedures or accountability tracking

items.evidence_required: Delegation procedures, recent examples of security responsibility transfers during incidents

items.title: Complex Issue Response
items.question: How does your team handle security issues that don't have clear-cut solutions or might impact business operations?

options.label: Complex issues have defined resolution processes with specific timeframes and decision criteria
Complex issues sometimes delayed beyond necessary analysis time without clear resolution path
Complex issues routinely deferred or avoided rather than resolved within reasonable timeframes

items.evidence_required: Recent complex security issue examples, resolution timelines, decision frameworks

items.title: Stress Response Documentation
items.question: Do you track patterns in security decision-making effectiveness during high-stress periods versus normal operations?

options.label: No observable pattern of decision delays during high-stress periods based on systematic tracking
Occasional patterns of slower decision-making under stress without systematic tracking
Consistent patterns of decision avoidance during high-stress situations

items.evidence_required: Decision-making metrics correlated with stress periods, incident analysis showing stress-decision patterns

items.title: Authority Conflict Resolution
items.question: What is your process when security requirements conflict with executive or departmental priorities?

options.label: Authority conflicts resolved through documented processes within 24 hours with clear resolution paths
Authority conflicts sometimes require external intervention to resolve without clear process
Authority conflicts remain unresolved or create ongoing security gaps

items.evidence_required: Recent authority conflict examples, conflict resolution procedures, resolution timelines

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: Tell me about a specific recent security incident and the decision timeline from initial detection to taking action.

scoring_guidance.green: Specific timeline provided showing decisions made within 4 hours, clear decision process
scoring_guidance.yellow: Timeline shows delays of 4-24 hours with procedural complications or unclear authority
scoring_guidance.red: Timeline >24 hours or unable to recall specific timeline indicating lack of decision process

followups.text: What prevented faster decision-making during this incident?
Who had authority to make the key decisions and were they available when needed?

items.text: What happens when security incidents occur outside normal business hours and your primary decision-makers are unavailable?

scoring_guidance.green: Clear backup authority structure with documented procedures and recent successful examples
scoring_guidance.yellow: Informal backup arrangements with some gaps or inconsistencies
scoring_guidance.red: Decisions delayed until primary personnel available or unclear backup authority

followups.text: Give me an example of an after-hours incident and how the decision process worked.
What authority do backup personnel have compared to primary decision-makers?

items.text: How often do key security personnel miss or reschedule security incident meetings?

scoring_guidance.green: >90% attendance with rare absences due to documented conflicts
scoring_guidance.yellow: 70-90% attendance with some pattern of avoidance
scoring_guidance.red: <70% attendance or regular last-minute cancellations without clear justification

followups.text: Has meeting attendance ever affected the quality or timeliness of incident response?
What is your policy for mandatory attendance at critical security meetings?

items.text: Describe a recent security issue that required difficult decisions affecting business operations. How long did it take to resolve?

scoring_guidance.green: Complex issue resolved within defined timeframes using documented decision framework
scoring_guidance.yellow: Complex issue delayed beyond necessary analysis time without clear resolution path
scoring_guidance.red: Complex issue deferred indefinitely or avoided rather than confronted and resolved

followups.text: What made this decision difficult and how did you work through the difficulty?
Looking back, was the delay in decision-making justified by the complexity?

items.text: When security requirements conflict with executive priorities, what happens?

scoring_guidance.green: Conflict resolved through documented escalation process with clear authority and timelines
scoring_guidance.yellow: Conflict resolution informal and time-consuming without clear process
scoring_guidance.red: Conflicts avoided, deferred, or remain unresolved creating ongoing security gaps

followups.text: Give me a specific recent example of such a conflict and how it was resolved.
How comfortable are security personnel with escalating conflicts to higher authority?

items.text: Do you notice differences in security team responsiveness during high-stress periods versus normal operations?

scoring_guidance.green: No significant difference, or systematic tracking shows consistent performance under stress
scoring_guidance.yellow: Informal awareness of slower responses under stress without systematic tracking
scoring_guidance.red: Clear pattern of decision delays or avoidance during high-stress situations

followups.text: What specific behaviors change when the team is under stress?
How do you support decision-making effectiveness during high-pressure situations?

items.text: Tell me about a time when security responsibilities were passed between multiple people during an active issue.

scoring_guidance.green: Clear handoff with documented transfer of authority and no loss of momentum
scoring_guidance.yellow: Informal handoff with some confusion or delays in decision continuity
scoring_guidance.red: Multiple handoffs creating decision paralysis or accountability gaps

followups.text: Did the delegation improve or delay incident resolution?
What procedures ensure accountability when security decisions are delegated?

subsections.title: Probing for Red Flags
subsections.description: Observable indicators that increase vulnerability score regardless of stated policies

items.label: "We need more time to analyze before making any security decisions..." (pattern of indefinite delay)
"It's better to escalate security decisions to senior leadership..." (systematic upward delegation)
"Security meetings conflict with other priorities..." (pattern of meeting avoidance)
"We're waiting for the right time to address that security issue..." (indefinite deferral)
"Complex security issues need committee review..." (decision paralysis through committee)
"I'd rather not make that call - let's see if someone else can decide..." (explicit avoidance)
"We don't track decision timelines - security is too complex for that..." (resistance to accountability)

continuous_validation.synthetic_testing: Inject simulated complex security scenarios monthly to test decision latency patterns
continuous_validation.correlation_analysis: Compare manual audit scores with automated decision timeline metrics (target correlation > 0.82)
continuous_validation.drift_detection: Kolmogorov-Smirnov test on decision latency distributions, recalibrate if p < 0.05

calibration.description: Ensure predicted avoidance probabilities match observed decision delay frequencies

success_metrics.formula: 50% reduction in decision time for routine incidents, 75% reduction for pre-authorized scenarios
success_metrics.baseline: Average time from security issue identification to action decision
success_metrics.target: Routine incidents <4 hours, critical incidents <2 hours within 90 days
success_metrics.measurement: Monthly tracking of incident response timelines with quarterly trend analysis

success_metrics.formula: Percentage of security issues properly escalated within documented timeframes
success_metrics.target: 95% compliance with escalation procedures and timeframes
success_metrics.measurement: Weekly review of escalation logs with monthly compliance reporting

success_metrics.formula: Comparison of decision-making speed between normal and high-stress periods
success_metrics.baseline: Current differential between normal and high-stress decision times
success_metrics.target: <20% difference in response times between normal and high-stress situations
success_metrics.measurement: Quarterly analysis of decision patterns correlated with organizational stress indicators

solutions.title: Automated Decision Support System
solutions.description: Implement decision trees and automated workflows that provide clear action steps for common security scenarios
solutions.implementation: Deploy decision support tools that reduce cognitive load during stress situations, include automatic escalation timers and pre-approved response procedures that eliminate decision paralysis, create clear action paths for different security scenario types
solutions.technical_controls: Decision tree automation, escalation timer systems, pre-approved response workflow engine, scenario-action mapping database

solutions.title: Authority Matrix Documentation
solutions.description: Create explicit authority matrices defining who can make what security decisions under various circumstances
solutions.implementation: Document clear authority levels for all security decision types, define escalation timeframes, establish alternate decision-makers to prevent bottlenecks, include emergency authorization procedures
solutions.technical_controls: Authority matrix database, decision routing automation, backup authority notification system, escalation timeframe tracking

solutions.title: Stress Inoculation Training Program
solutions.description: Conduct regular incident response simulations that progressively increase complexity and stress levels
solutions.implementation: Build team tolerance for high-pressure security decisions through graduated exposure, include scenarios requiring difficult business conversations and authority confrontation, practice decision-making under increasing stress conditions
solutions.technical_controls: Simulation platform, progressive difficulty scaling, stress monitoring during exercises, performance tracking system
solutions.timeline: ongoing program with 60 day initial setup

solutions.title: Decision Timeline Monitoring
solutions.description: Implement tracking systems that monitor security decision latency and alert when decisions exceed established timeframes
solutions.implementation: Deploy automated monitoring of decision timelines, create dashboards showing decision patterns and bottlenecks, implement alerts when decisions exceed timeframes, enable identification of avoidance behaviors before security impact
solutions.technical_controls: Decision timeline tracking system, automated alerting for delays, bottleneck visualization dashboard, pattern analysis engine

solutions.title: Buddy System Protocol
solutions.description: Establish paired decision-making for high-stress security situations
solutions.implementation: Require two personnel to jointly approve action plans for complex scenarios, reduce individual anxiety about making wrong decisions while ensuring decisions still get made promptly, create buddy pairings with complementary skills and stress responses
solutions.technical_controls: Buddy assignment system, joint approval workflow, decision documentation platform, backup buddy coverage automation

solutions.title: Pre-Authorization Framework
solutions.description: Develop pre-authorized response procedures for common security scenarios that eliminate in-the-moment decision requirements
solutions.implementation: Create pre-approved response procedures for common security scenarios, include business impact pre-approvals and stakeholder communication templates, reduce decision friction during incident response
solutions.technical_controls: Pre-authorization database, automated response procedure retrieval, stakeholder approval tracking, impact pre-assessment system

risk_scenarios.title: Extended Dwell Time Exploitation
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers time their activities during periods when key security personnel exhibit avoidance behaviors such as end-of-quarter business pressure or major system updates
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Timing attacks to coincide with organizational stress periods when decision-making is impaired
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Delayed security response allows attackers additional weeks to establish persistence, steal data, and prepare lateral movement before detection systems are properly investigated
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Target 2013 - security teams delayed response to breach indicators allowing 19-day window for attacker activity

risk_scenarios.title: Authority Escalation Attack
risk_scenarios.description: Social engineers deliberately create security incidents that require confronting senior executives or business unit leaders
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Creating security incidents that trigger authority conflict and avoidance responses
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Security personnel avoid direct confrontation while attackers use the time gap to complete data exfiltration or system compromise
risk_scenarios.historical_example: BEC attacks where security personnel avoid challenging apparent executive requests

risk_scenarios.title: Complexity Overwhelm Campaign
risk_scenarios.description: Sophisticated attackers launch multi-vector attacks designed to create cognitive overload in security operations teams
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Multi-system, multi-vector attack creating decision paralysis through complexity
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Overwhelmed personnel avoid making rapid containment decisions, allowing attackers to exploit decision paralysis for system pivoting and persistence establishment
risk_scenarios.historical_example: SolarWinds 2020 - attack sophistication created decision paralysis in multiple organizations

risk_scenarios.title: Crisis Decision Exploitation
risk_scenarios.description: During organizational stress periods (layoffs, mergers, system outages), attackers launch campaigns requiring security decisions conflicting with business continuity
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Exploiting organizational stress periods when flight response is heightened
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Security personnel's flight response leads to delayed patching, reduced monitoring, and acceptance of temporary security workarounds that attackers exploit for long-term access
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Attacks during merger periods when security decision-making is compromised by organizational uncertainty
